conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas at 600 K, we can analyze the given p-T graph.
The graph shows a linear relationship between pressure (p) and temperature (T).
From the graph, at 200 K, the pressure is 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa.
At 400 K, the pressure is 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa.

premise: The pressure at 200 K is 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa and at 400 K is 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa.
conclusion: The slope (m) can be calculated as m = (1.0 × 10⁵ Pa - 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa) / (400 K - 200 K) = 0.25 × 10³ Pa/K.

premise: The slope is 0.25 × 10³ Pa/K and using the point (200 K, 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa).
conclusion: Using the point-slope form of a line, p = mT + c, c = 0, so the equation is p = 0.25 × 10³ × T.
Substitute T = 600 K into the equation: p = 0.25 × 10³ × 600 = 1.5 × 10⁵ Pa.
